questions.question: Who is the primary buyer of this product?
questions.why: Knowing the buyer role helps shape pricing, messaging, and sales motion.

options.label: VP/Head of Sales
options.detail: Decision maker with budget authority in revenue teams
options.reasoning: Revenue team leaders are the most common buyers for sales productivity tools based on market evidence.

options.label: Revenue/Sales Operations Lead
options.detail: Operational buyer focused on process optimization

options.label: Founder/CEO (SMB)
options.detail: Founder-led purchase at early-stage companies

questions.question: What type of company is your ideal customer?
questions.why: Company type determines channel strategy and product requirements.

options.label: B2B SaaS (50-500)
options.detail: Mid-market SaaS companies with structured sales teams
options.reasoning: Mid-market B2B SaaS companies have the budget and team structure to benefit most from this category.

options.label: SMB (1-50)
options.detail: Small businesses with lean teams

options.label: Enterprise (500+)
options.detail: Large organizations with complex procurement

questions.question: What event triggers the need for your product?
questions.why: Trigger events help time outreach and craft messaging that resonates.

options.label: Hiring new sales reps
options.detail: Team growth creates need for better follow-up processes
options.reasoning: Hiring events are the strongest observable trigger for this product category based on competitive evidence.

options.label: Rising customer churn
options.detail: Churn signals broken post-sale communication

options.label: Revenue target increase
options.detail: Ambitious targets require better pipeline efficiency

questions.question: How do prospects currently solve this problem?
questions.why: Understanding workarounds reveals positioning opportunities and switching costs.

options.label: Manual notes + CRM updates
options.detail: Reps manually log call notes and set follow-up reminders
options.reasoning: Manual processes are the most common workaround, representing the largest addressable wedge for automation.

options.label: Basic call recording tool
options.detail: Using Gong/Chorus but not for follow-up automation

options.label: No formal process
options.detail: Follow-ups are ad hoc and often forgotten

questions.question: What measurable outcome would prove value to the buyer?
questions.why: Clear metrics help validate product-market fit and drive purchasing decisions.

options.label: Reduce lead leakage by 30%+
options.detail: Fewer leads falling through the cracks after initial calls
options.reasoning: Lead leakage reduction is the most concrete, measurable outcome that maps directly to revenue impact.

options.label: Save 5+ hours/week per rep
options.detail: Time saved on manual follow-up and CRM data entry

options.label: Increase demo-to-close by 20%
options.detail: Better follow-up cadence improves conversion rates

questions.question: What team size does your ideal customer have?
questions.why: Team size affects pricing strategy, onboarding complexity, and support needs.
questions.custom_placeholder: Enter a custom team size range...

options.label: 5-20 people
options.detail: Small team, fast decisions, price-sensitive

options.label: 20-100 people
options.detail: Growing team with dedicated sales function
options.reasoning: This size typically has a dedicated sales function but not yet entrenched tooling — ideal adoption window.

options.label: 100+ people
options.detail: Established org with multiple sales teams

questions.question: How long is a typical sales cycle for your product?
questions.why: Sales cycle length determines the right sales motion and cash flow planning.

options.label: Self-serve (days)
options.detail: Product-led, free trial or freemium

options.label: 1-4 weeks
options.detail: Quick demo-to-close with champion buy-in
options.reasoning: Short cycles match the mid-market ICP and keep cash flow manageable for early-stage teams.

options.label: 1-3 months
options.detail: Multiple stakeholders, procurement involved

questions.question: What integrations are critical for your product?
questions.why: Integration requirements affect technical scope and time-to-market.

options.label: CRM (HubSpot/Salesforce)
options.detail: Core integration for data sync
options.reasoning: CRM integration is table stakes for sales tools — without it, adoption stalls at the pilot stage.

options.label: Communication tools (Zoom/Teams)
options.detail: Call recording and meeting integration

options.label: Standalone first
options.detail: Launch without integrations, add later

questions.question: How aware are your prospects of competing solutions?
questions.why: Competitive awareness shapes your positioning strategy — category creation vs. category wedge.

options.label: Highly aware
options.detail: Prospects actively compare solutions in this category

options.label: Somewhat aware
options.detail: Know the problem exists but haven't explored solutions deeply
options.reasoning: Moderate awareness means the problem is felt but not solved — best wedge positioning opportunity.

options.label: Not aware
options.detail: Don't know a solution category exists — greenfield

questions.question: What's the strongest signal that prospects would pay for this?
questions.why: WTP evidence is critical for pricing confidence and investor conversations.

options.label: Already paying for alternatives
options.detail: Budget allocated, switching cost is the barrier
options.reasoning: Existing budget allocation is the strongest WTP signal — it proves the category has established spend.

options.label: Expressed pain in interviews
options.detail: Verbal confirmation but no spend yet

options.label: Assumption based on market size
options.detail: No direct signal yet — needs validation
